sarahharris: Thank you. I live in the Whitehall District, and I wanted to thank you for continuing to uphold the masking policy, given our current rate of community transmission. I was going to cite statistics about how relying on vaccinations as the primary mitigation strategy is inherently inequitable, given the fact that many people remain unvaccinated or under vaccinated for reasons that have nothing to do with choice. I can remind you that COVID-19 disproportionately impacts black, brown, immunocompromised, and low-income families and families without the ability to work remotely much more significantly than white or affluent families, families who aren't already dealing with significant health challenges, and families with flexible work options. In the absence of readily available and accessible testing opportunities, masking remains our most equitable mitigation strategy to limit the spread of COVID-19 and to keep schools open. To be clear, I share the urgency to return to normal. I recognize that declining mental health among children and teens is a major concern, but there are many factors that have contributed to student mental health decline and masks are not one of them. There's a loss of normalcy, yes, but also the literal loss of loved ones and family income disruption and loss of social interaction and endless anxiety over all the different ways COVID has or could impact their lives. There has been fear and not just fear of COVID. In our county, in one semester alone, there have been multiple social media threats that have led to lockdowns and arrests. That's traumatic for children and teens. active shooter drills, divisive politics, the existential threat to our democracy, world leaders' inability to take substantive action to combat the climate crisis, angry parents yelling at school board members or suing school divisions over a curriculum that includes fact-based history lessons and policies that make schools more inclusive of all students. What are we doing? Mask wearing is not the problem, and fear is not ruling our lives, but compassion should. We want our community to be healthy. We want our children to learn the truth. We want our kids to be safe. We want our kids to care about each other. And everyone wants our kids to be in school. So masking for now is a way to keep our schools open. And it's also how we show our neighbors and especially our healthcare workers that we care. It's literally the least we can do for each other. Thank you.<|eot_id|>

And whereas among the school division's four values is its young people, specifically their academic and personal development, their health and well-being, And whereas in response to the closure of schools, the division's child nutrition department immediately began to plan to meet the needs of all children for healthy breakfast and lunches on a daily basis. And whereas within one business day of the governor's closure announcement, Child Nutrition Team members, under the guidance of Director Christina Pitzenberger, had organized a food distribution program. And whereas the program began with six school sites throughout the county, serving more than 1,000 meals a day to students and their siblings 18 years of old and younger. And whereas on March 23rd, The governor extended the closure of all K-12 schools in the Commonwealth through the end of the current academic year, and whereas the Child Nutrition Office continued to monitor the need among its students and all communities across the county for healthy meals and to work with the Department of Transportation in setting up additional food distribution sites, And whereas, as the result of this ongoing planning and teamwork, the office now distributes breakfast and lunches to students in 21 locations at schools and communities. And whereas, since March 17th, the Child Nutrition Office has provided more than 30,000 meals to students from all schools and locations in the county, and is continuing to evaluate the needs to further expand this service. Now therefore be it resolved that the Albemarle County School Board expresses its deep appreciation to Ms. Pitsenberger and her highly dedicated and skilled team for their invaluable support in meeting the nutritional and health needs of thousands of Albemarle County public school students and their siblings, and for doing so through such an expeditious and increasingly inclusive plan. And be it further resolved, the school board also salutes the contributions of the transportation department, its director James Foley, and his team for enabling the food distribution program to bring its services directly to the neighborhoods where students reside, thereby expanding participation in this vitally beneficial program. jonnoalcaro: I'm, I was very focused on teachers I was very focused on administrators, but classified staff is one of the most important groups, you know, in our schools and our, in our buildings, and they mean so much. to our students, and so the import of them stands out to me every single year. The things that grabbed me in here were the retention rate, and I see that the retention rate is kind of steady in the 70 to 80%. But I think that's still a 24% departure rate is high. And I'm noticing that the retirements have jumped up each of the last three years. And so we're now we're five percentage points above where we were back in 17, 18. And I'd love to know some of the reasons behind it. I mean, I saw in here that through exit surveys, the main reasons for Leaving the job was personal moving from the area retirement 13% just seems like a big number. And I'm not, I'm not saying that people shouldn't be retiring when they're wanting to retire, you know, but I wonder if there are some retirements that people are doing that might be a little bit early. And, but obviously the one that I think you all are probably paying attention to is the third one with the job related issues, dissatisfaction with policies, practices, et cetera. And so for a group that is so important to our everyday existence and the wellbeing of our students, Those are the three things, whether it's the retention rate, the retirement rate, and the factors that were given during the exit surveys. jeffvergales: We've, absolutely. We've learned a lot about the immune system in relation to the COVID vaccine, significantly just in the last four to six weeks or so. You've seen some trials come out also with the Johnson & Johnson and Novavax vaccine, which the Johnson & Johnson is a single dose vaccine. There's a very specific reason that the Pfizer and the Moderna were put out as two-dose vaccines, and that was because initial studies suggested that they were probably about 75% to 80% effective after the first shot. And I remind you that we set the bar initially through the FDA at 50%. If we get 50% effective excuse me, 50% efficacy of a vaccine within any season, we're otherwise pleased, especially for a virus like this that spreads exponentially, that can have significant effects on its ability to protect somebody. The reason, though, that you did not see it stop at one shot and it go as a two-dose vaccine was purely because they found that the efficacy raised up to around 90% to 95% and 100% for preventing severe disease once you got that second dose. But that is why the FDA ended up approving it. And so while we obviously can't tell somebody, oh, you're fine, don't ever get the second, you're almost a whole way there. People should take solace in the fact that if they have one dose of the vaccine, that they've already begun the significant issue of developing immunity to it. And so I would encourage, and I've encouraged a lot of people, again, a lot of the teachers that asked me that very exact question last Friday when I was doing vaccines there, as I said, this is a big step. The second one is the one that seems to secure the memory response a little bit better. One just quick follow-up question is, with the first shot, is there still or is there a two-week period before that really takes effect as it is with the second shot? We think that you've probably managed to generate an immune response so that you actually have circulating antibodies sometime around that seven to 10-day mark after the first shot. And so that seems to be kind of the line in the sand that a lot of us that a lot of us are utilizing. With that being said, I know you guys have all seen also that the recommendation is still going to be that the vaccine is just one layer of mitigation and that even after people are fully vaccinated. We don't know we know that it is a good way to prevent people from beginning severe illness. we have no idea about its ability to prevent people from spreading the disease. And that's why you're not going to be seeing vaccination programs as part of mitigation strategies for large organizations because you're, you know, supplant things like mask wearing and physical distancing and all of the other information. And so I would say the vaccine as a general rule is that we excuse me, I apologize, the vaccine is a general rule for us, is a very personal decision of allowing, making sure that we can promise somebody is, or not promise, but get close to that, that somebody is not going to individually become sick. But I would encourage you not to think of the vaccine as a way to prevent spread within a school. We have absolutely no idea its ability to prevent that. And that's why all the data that I presented earlier is without vaccination, and I think needs to be kind of continued to be kept in that context. For an individual teacher, that's a different story. If we're concerned about individual at-risk people, the vaccine can make a noticeable, noticeable difference. But we do not know its ability to help prevent spread through schools. This resolution of the Board of Education of Albemarle County Virginia School Board adopting order number 21-3 of the Director of Emergency Management for the County of Albemarle, Virginia. Whereas the school board recognizes that Albemarle County and the rest of the state of Virginia and the United States are in the midst of a worldwide COVID-19 pandemic that has resulted in more than 600,000 deaths in the United States. And whereas the school board has responded to the challenges brought about by the COVID-19 pandemic, providing students and staff members with the technology and resources necessary to ensure the efficient delivery of instruction virtually and in person. And whereas the school board has a substantial public interest in protecting the health and safety of its students, staff and community, and ensuring that the school division can provide staff and students with a safe and effective educational environment that supports student achievement. And whereas school division staff at all levels are essential to the day-to-day operations of the school division and are responsible for the thorough and efficient education of all students and their social and emotional well-being. And whereas a surge of COVID-19 cases has recently occurred, largely resulting from the Delta variant, also known as B.1.617.2, a highly transmissible virus that impacts individuals regardless of age, And whereas over 90% of COVID-19 infections are currently occurring in individuals who have not been vaccinated against COVID-19. And whereas the overwhelming scientific evidence has established that the vaccines authorized by the FDA for emergency use are safe and effective. and recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for all individuals except children under 12 years of age and certain others, and whereas the school board has the responsibility to prevent the outbreak and spread of COVID-19 infections in its schools and other facilities, and whereas the Director of Emergency Management for the County of Albemarle, Virginia has issued Order Number 21-3 pursuant to Virginia Code 44-146.21c, mandating vaccines, vaccinations, or periodic testing for COVID-19 for the employees of the County of Albemarle. Now, therefore, be it resolved that the school board finds that there exists a public health emergency that requires action to safeguard students and staff against the risks of infection, illness, hospitalization, and death from COVID-19. The school board adopts order number 21 dash three and will work in partnership with the county of Albemarle in the implementation of this order to control the spread of coven 19 in the school division and community. The administration of the school division is directed to develop procedures for the implementation of this resolution that are based upon order number 21-2 as modified to reflect the specific operations of the school division and school board policies, regulations, and code of conduct, and otherwise take all other actions necessary to carry out this mandate. The school board hereby delegates to the superintendent the authority to implement and modify vaccination and testing procedures based on changing conditions and to maintain conformance with the requirements of the CDC, Virginia Department of Health, Blue Ridge Health District, and other applicable health authorities.
